awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms and Functions of Intermittent Synchronization in Neural and Other Living Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Living nature is cyclic: The heart contracts and expands, sleep and wakefulness replace each other, populations of wild animals increase and decrease, and neural cells in our brains exchange oscillatory electrical signals as we think and move. Whenever biological oscillators interact, they mutually adjust their rhythms, that is, they synchronize. This synchronization needs to be fine-tuned. For example, too much of synchronization between neural cells is associated with motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, too little is associated with impaired cognition. This research project will investigate the mechanisms of how biological oscillators go in and out of synch in time, an important problem that has not been extensively studied. Biological systems are very adaptable to the changes in the environment, and this research will explore associations between adaptability and dynamics of synchrony. The study will utilize mathematical and computational models of neural and other biological oscillators, complemented by the analysis of available experimental data. The project aims to clarify the mechanisms of synchronization in neural and other living systems. Importantly, this will not only assist in understanding of healthy normal functioning of biological oscillators, but will also advance understanding of mechanisms of pathologies -- much-needed knowledge for the treatments of several brain disorders (e.g., Parkinson's disease, addiction, and schizophrenia) and other pathological conditions. In addition, young scholars will be engaged in this research and will get critical experience in biomathematics, contributing to the preparation of a modern workforce able to tackle life sciences questions with mathematical techniques.

In more technical terms, oscillations and synchrony are recognized as important mechanisms underlying many physiological phenomena, in particular neural ones. Excessively strong or weak synchrony is associated with several neurological and neuropsychiatric dysfunctions. Neural synchrony frequently varies in time. Few long-desynchronized dynamics intervals may be functionally different from many short desynchronizations, although the average synchrony may be the same. Recent studies of different neural systems reported the strong prevalence of short desynchronizations. This research will explore the nature and function of these short desynchronizations in neural systems and analyze temporal patterning of synchrony in other living systems. Several questions will be answered: What are the mechanisms of short desynchronizations in neural systems? What function do they serve? What changes in the patterning of synchrony may lead to what dysfunctions? What are the differences in the temporal patterning of synchrony in neural and non-neural living systems? Mathematical techniques will explain how the patterning of synchrony contributes to the adaptability and efficiency of living systems. From a mathematical standpoint, the project will advance understanding of how some experimentally-relevant universal dynamics may emerge in a class of moderately-coupled neural-like oscillators.

por.por_cntn:
Rhythmic oscillatory activity of neural cells in the brain is important for many brain functions. Synchronization of this activity is involved in a number of motor and cognitive phenomena. This synchronization needs to be fine-tuned. For example, both too much and too little synchronization between neural cells is associated with several cognitive impairments. This research project was aimed at the understanding of the mechanisms of how neural (and more broadly, biological) oscillatory systems go in and out of synchronous state in time, that is the fine temporal structure of synchronized dynamics.

 

As a result of the research within the framework of this project, we found several potential mechanisms that may regulate the fine temporal structure of the intermittent neural synchrony. Neural oscillations in the brain in general show a tendency to get out of synch for a relatively short (although potentially numerous) intervals of time (provided there is some level of synchrony is present overall). This is shown in some earlier studies as well as in our research in this project. Using mathematical modelling we found out how synaptic plasticity (a very common property of the connections between neural cells) may alter synchronized dynamics in the network in several ways depending on the time-scale of action of plasticity. Our analysis suggests that the action of the spike-timing-dependent plasticity tends to promote dynamics with short desynchronizations. This dynamic is very similar to those observed in experiments. Moreover, the temporal characteristics of short desynchronization dynamics can be varied with the variation of the plasticity properties, which also makes it similar to the variations observed in experimental and clinical data from the brain.

 

Another mechanism of the effects on the temporal patterning of neural synchrony is the action of the noise. Noise is ubiquitous in neural systems, one of its sources is the noisy properties of ionic channels that drive the electrical activity of neurons. While it is well known that synchrony strength generally degrades with noise, we found that noise also affects the temporal patterning of synchrony. Noise, at a sufficient intensity (yet too weak to substantially affect synchrony strength), promotes dynamics with predominantly short (although potentially very numerous) desynchronizations. Thus, channel noise may be one of the mechanisms contributing to the short desynchronization dynamics observed in experimental studies.

 

Furthermore, we investigated how temporal patterning of neural synchrony can be varied independently of the synchrony strength. In very small networks of oscillators, change in the strength of connections affects the synchrony strength. However, we studied more biologically realistic models, with inhibitory and excitatory connections, and we found that the change in the temporal patterning of synchronous dynamics can be affected by synaptic strength (even if the average synchrony strength is staying the same), which is a very physiologically plausible mechanism. Synaptic changes are characteristic of many physiological and pathophysiological conditions and therefore one of the ways how those changes can lead to the changes in cognitive and motor behavior is via the changes in the temporal patterning of synchrony, that may affect the information processing in the brain. We found how these phenomena may happen in medium size neural networks responding to an input signal.

 

To consider the issues of the temporal synchronization patterning in a broader context of living systems, we considered the properties of potential functions of the intermittent synchrony in biological oscillators beyond neural ones. We considered modes of oscillatory populations of predator-prey type in ecology, coupled via animal migration. Ecological data suggests that migration levels are small, and this is exactly the case leading to relatively weak and intermittent synchrony between populations. The coupled differential equations models are in some ways similar to those used in neural modeling. Even though the actual biological systems are very much different, the similarities in the temporal patterning of synchronous dynamics in these two very different types of biological oscillators may point that this patterning assists in the overall adaptability of these oscillators to the changes in the environment.

 

This project also provided training and professional development for multiple undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral students as well as assisted k-12 students with the science education.
